DOC.HEAD: Argentine Currency Plunges 27 Percent in Single Day
DOC.TEXT: The government of President Carlos Menem suffered an economic setback Tuesday when the Argentine currency lost 27 percent of its value against the U.S. dollar in a single day. At the close of the business day, foreign exchange houses offered 1,700 australs for each dollar. Last Friday, the market rate was 1,230 australs per dollar. Banks were closed Monday for Christmas. After weeks of pressure against the austral, the government Dec. 10 formally devalued the currency by 34 percent, bringing the official and free market rates briefly in parity. However, the austral plunge anew after interest rates soared as did prices and wage demands by workers. On Dec. 15, Economy Minister Nestor Rapanelli resigned, and his successor, Antonio Gonzalez, three days later freed the exchange rate and lifted most price controls. Menem has struggled with the economy ever since taking office July 8. Gonzalez is Menem's third economy minister, and Rodolfo Rossi is the third Central Bank president. So far this year, Argentina has had six economy ministers and five Central Bank presidents.
